replies.bodyText:
So I think we have a couple of options:


Current implementation Allow the implementation classes to handle the error in whatever manner they see appropriate. ApplyRemoteConflictHandler for example, does this by making the user provide an instance of an DataStoreErrorHandler in the constructor.


Alternative 1 add a Consumer<Throwable> as a third parameter


Alternative 2 add a DataStoreErrorHandler as a third parameter. This would force any implementation of DataStoreConflictHandler to use an error handler.


Thoughts?

It would, it it wasn't for those "check for default value" if statement in the setters. Basically, the logic is as follows:

Create a builder using the settings from amplifyconfiguration.json. (builder(pluginJson))
Then call the setters for each of the properties of the builder by passing in the corresponding value from userProvidedConfiguration.

This results in any non-default values provided in userProvidedConfiguration to override whatever was in the JSON, which I believe is the behavior we were looking for.
The other option I considered was to make the scalar values in the configuration object nullable. We would then only override using non-null values from userProvidedConfiguration. This in turn, added some complexity where I'd have to create a config object without default values and then pass the burden of checking whether or not they were null down to the wherever the settings are actually read.
Let me know if this makes sense.

timeline.bodyText:
I guess there are two ways of looking at this:

The current view:


The orchestrator is an optional component. It's presence is determined by the content of the configuration. If the configuration does not permit remote sync, then don't create an orchestrator.


The original view:


The orchestrator is a data store component, it is constructed at the same time as the plugin. Later, if the configuration determines that sync should be enabled, the orchestrator is started.

Realistically, the only concrete concern is whether or not orchestrator is null at the time you call start. So long as configuration is definitely done by the time initialize() rolls around, you should be good.

replies.bodyText:
Changes made in the latest commit
With the latest commit, the following rules should apply:

Read settings from config file (if any)
Read settings from user-provided POJO (if any). Apply any non-null values
Fill in any missing fields with default values if instructed to do so (More on that below)

Changes to DataStoreConfiguration.Builder

Moved most of the logic out of the DataStoreConfiguration methods
Added a constructor that takes an instance of DataStoreConfiguration as the user-provided settings in addition to the JSON values
Added a field to the Builder called ensureDefaults. This field is only set to true if the new constructor is called.
Modified build() method to populate defaults if  ensureDefaults is true

Changes to DataStoreConfiguration

Marked two builder methods(builder(JSONObject), and builder(JSONObject, DataStoreConfiguration)) as package private so they should only be callable internally. This leaves the parameter-less builder() method as the only option when user's want to create an instance of DataStoreConfiguration to pass in overrides. When created via this method, the builder's build() method will leave any scalar fields not explicitly set by the user as null.
Simplified getters and added a new getter for getSyncIntervalInMinutes
